ticket.title: Add inverse polymorphic association support
ticket.original-body:
The attached patch adds support for :inverse_of on a polymorphic belongs_to association.
require 'active_record' ActiveRecord::Base.establish_connection('adapter' => "sqlite3", 'database' => ":memory:") ActiveRecord::Schema.define do create_table :parents do end create_table :children do |t| t.integer :parent_id t.string :parent_type end end
class Parent < ActiveRecord::Base has_one :child, :as => :parent, :inverse_of => :parent end
class Child < ActiveRecord::Base belongs_to :parent, :polymorphic => true, :inverse_of => :child end
parent = Parent.new(:child => Child.new) parent.child.parent.target.equal?(parent) # true
ticket.latest-body:
The attached patch adds support for :inverse_of on a polymorphic belongs_to association.
require 'active_record' ActiveRecord::Base.establish_connection('adapter' => "sqlite3", 'database' => ":memory:") ActiveRecord::Schema.define do create_table :parents do end create_table :children do |t| t.integer :parent_id t.string :parent_type end end
class Parent < ActiveRecord::Base has_one :child, :as => :parent, :inverse_of => :parent end
class Child < ActiveRecord::Base belongs_to :parent, :polymorphic => true, :inverse_of => :child end
parent = Parent.new(:child => Child.new) parent.child.parent.target.equal?(parent) # true
ticket.original-body-html:
The attached patch adds support for :inverse_of on a polymorphic belongs_to association.

require 'active_record'
ActiveRecord::Base.establish_connection('adapter' => "sqlite3", 'database' => ":memory:")
ActiveRecord::Schema.define do
  create_table :parents do
  end
  create_table :children do |t|
    t.integer :parent_id
    t.string :parent_type
  end
end

class Parent < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_one :child, :as => :parent, :inverse_of => :parent
end

class Child < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :parent, :polymorphic => true, :inverse_of => :child
end

parent = Parent.new(:child => Child.new)
parent.child.parent.target.equal?(parent)  # true

version.body:
The attached patch adds support for :inverse_of on a polymorphic belongs_to association.
require 'active_record' ActiveRecord::Base.establish_connection('adapter' => "sqlite3", 'database' => ":memory:") ActiveRecord::Schema.define do create_table :parents do end create_table :children do |t| t.integer :parent_id t.string :parent_type end end
class Parent < ActiveRecord::Base has_one :child, :as => :parent, :inverse_of => :parent end
class Child < ActiveRecord::Base belongs_to :parent, :polymorphic => true, :inverse_of => :child end
parent = Parent.new(:child => Child.new) parent.child.parent.target.equal?(parent) # true
version.body-html:
The attached patch adds support for :inverse_of on a polymorphic belongs_to association.

require 'active_record'
ActiveRecord::Base.establish_connection('adapter' => "sqlite3", 'database' => ":memory:")
ActiveRecord::Schema.define do
  create_table :parents do
  end
  create_table :children do |t|
    t.integer :parent_id
    t.string :parent_type
  end
end

class Parent < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_one :child, :as => :parent, :inverse_of => :parent
end

class Child < ActiveRecord::Base
  belongs_to :parent, :polymorphic => true, :inverse_of => :child
end

parent = Parent.new(:child => Child.new)
parent.child.parent.target.equal?(parent)  # true
version.title: Add inverse polymorphic association support

version.body:
I’m wondering, why do you need to fix all these other tests? Eg:
@@@ diff - m = Man.find(:first, :include => :interests) + m = Man.find(:first, :conditions => {:name => 'Gordon'}, :include => :interests) @@@
Is it simply because you want to use a specific fixture? Or does the patch somehow change existing functionality elsewhere?
version.body-html:
I’m wondering, why do you need to fix all these other tests? Eg:

-    m = Man.find(:first, :include => :interests)
+    m = Man.find(:first, :conditions => {:name => 'Gordon'}, :include => :interests)

Is it simply because you want to use a specific fixture? Or does the patch somehow change existing functionality elsewhere?
version.title: Add inverse polymorphic association support

version.body: Oh, and it applies and runs :)
version.title: Add inverse polymorphic association support

version.body:
George's above patch is good. However, attached is a new patch that:
a) includes George's patch tweaked to apply cleanly on top of my extra tests patch for #3513 b) adds another test for checking that polymorphic belongs_to associations can be assigned via direct accessor not just the .replace method c) provides a slightly more robust we_can_set_the_inverse_on_this? method for polymorphic belongs_to associations.
version.body-html:
George's above patch is good. However, attached is a new patch that:

a) includes George's patch tweaked to apply cleanly on top of my extra tests patch for #3513
b) adds another test for checking that polymorphic belongs_to associations can be assigned via direct accessor not just the .replace method
c) provides a slightly more robust we_can_set_the_inverse_on_this? method for polymorphic belongs_to associations.
version.title: Add inverse polymorphic association support

version.body:
One concern I have is that a polymorphic belongs_to using :inverse_of will *never* throw an InverseOfAssociationNotFoundError if the supplied :inverse_of doesn't actually match. This breaks symmetry with the other :inverse_of associations, but I'm not sure exactly what the correct place to throw such an error might be. We can't throw it during class definition, as the :inverse_of depends on the class of the polymorphic instance, but throwing it during assignment (or load) seems a tad late in the process.
Note, I don't think this should hold up this patch though.
version.body-html:
One concern I have is that a polymorphic belongs_to using :inverse_of will never throw an InverseOfAssociationNotFoundError if the supplied :inverse_of doesn't actually match. This breaks symmetry with the other :inverse_of associations, but I'm not sure exactly what the correct place to throw such an error might be. We can't throw it during class definition, as the :inverse_of depends on the class of the polymorphic instance, but throwing it during assignment (or load) seems a tad late in the process.

Note, I don't think this should hold up this patch though.
version.title: Add inverse polymorphic association support

version.body:
In response to Eloy's comments on IRC, the attached patch now makes polymorphic_inverse_of on Reflection throw an InverseOfAssociationNotFoundError if the supplied associated_class doesn't have the correct association on it.
There are 2 tests for this that appear to test the same thing, but I think they are subtly different:
1. test that it throws if the association is broken (e.g. nothing has the correct inverse - it would throw regardless of what we try to assign) 2. test that it throws if the association is fine, but the instance being assigned doesn't have the correct association (e.g. we can assign some things, but not others)
version.body-html:
In response to Eloy's comments on IRC, the attached patch now makes polymorphic_inverse_of on Reflection throw an InverseOfAssociationNotFoundError if the supplied associated_class doesn't have the correct association on it.

There are 2 tests for this that appear to test the same thing, but I think they are subtly different:

  1. test that it throws if the association is broken (e.g. nothing has the correct inverse - it would throw regardless of what we try to assign)
  2. test that it throws if the association is fine, but the instance being assigned doesn't have the correct association (e.g. we can assign some things, but not others)
version.title: Add inverse polymorphic association support

version.body: @Murray: I applied your last patch to 2-3-stable. I hope you don't mind I removed a few lines of code. Namely, returning ‘nil’ from an ‘else’ clause isn't necessary.
version.body-html: @Murray: I applied your last patch to 2-3-stable. I hope you don't mind I removed a few lines of code. Namely, returning ‘nil’ from an ‘else’ clause isn't necessary.

version.title: Add inverse polymorphic association support

version.body:
(from [603b28c84c1ba1d013247fee450d82f015aaefb3]) Provide a slightly more robust we_can_set_the_inverse_on_this? method for polymorphic belongs_to associations. [#3520 state:resolved]
Also add a new test for polymorphic belongs_to that test direct accessor assignment, not just .replace assignment.
Signed-off-by: Eloy Duran <eloy.de.enige@gmail.com> http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/603b28c84c1ba1d013247fee450d82f015aaefb3
version.body-html:
(from [603b28c84c1ba1d013247fee450d82f015aaefb3]) Provide a slightly more robust we_can_set_the_inverse_on_this? method for polymorphic belongs_to associations. [#3520 state:resolved]

Also add a new test for polymorphic belongs_to that test direct accessor assignment, not just .replace assignment.

Signed-off-by: Eloy Duran eloy.de.enige@gmail.com
http://github.com/rails/rails/commit/603b28c84c1ba1d013247fee450d82...

version.body: This supra footwear is called a modern vintage and has been since their introduction in 2003 where they began in Europe. Every supra shoes has some type of ornament, adornment or hardware and is comprised of aged leather that is bought from around the world. These supra uk are culturally engaging and allow for the woman wearing them to be enveloped in luxury.With new cuts and styles and hand stitched shoes, these timberland boots, heels or flats will make every foot look like it stepped out of vintage Hollywood. This timberland shoes have been worn and coveted by many of the most famous females in recent history. One such coach outlet, Jennifer Aniston, wears them in public and at home.This company makes many different unique styles of bags outlet from ankle booties to sandals, pumps, moncler jackets online, platforms and wedges. One louis vuitton bag in particular is ideal for the gothic style sense; it is patent leather and laces up the front of the shaft. There are also zippers on each side, and this shoe offers a flat heel of a half inch.Another great moncler jackets sale is featured in People's Style Watch and is called a platform bootie. This ture religion jeans has a raised panel in front of the ankle as well as a heel that measures 4.5 inches. The front offers a leather bandage appearance and is considered high fashion.
